Award.AwardTitle: Stereoselective Construction of Difficult Glycosidic Linkages
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jianglong Zhu of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at University of Toledo and Professor Xiaohua Li of the Department of Natural Sciences at University of Michigan-Dearborn are collaborating to develop novel approaches for stereoselective construction of difficult glycosidic linkages. This research has potential in the synthesis of carbohydrates by investigating new approaches to the stereoselective synthesis of structurally challenging and biologically valuable glycosidic linkages. By carrying out this project, the PIs will provide education and training opportunities for high school students, K-12 science teachers, undergraduate and graduate students, as well as visiting assistant professors. The PIs are recruiting women, groups underrepresented in the chemical sciences, and those from financially disadvantaged families to participate in this research. In addition, The PIs are participating in various outreach activities to promote teaching, training, and learning in chemical sciences.

The research is targeting the construction of difficult glycosidic linkages such as beta-mannopyranosides and alpha-thioglycosides. Specifically, stereoselective synthesis of beta-mannopyranosides is targeted via anomeric O-alkylation under dual control of kinetic anomeric and chelation effects. This umpolung-type beta-mannosylation is being used to synthesize N-linked glycans. The stereoselective synthesis of S-linked-thioglycosides uses umpolung S-glycosylation through sulfenylation of the axial glycosyl lithium species. Collectively, these synthetic approaches have the potential to add a significant new dimension to the set of available methodologies to make glycosides.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under the support of this NSF grant, we have developed a new stereoselective β-mannosylation via Cs2CO3-mediated anomeric O-alkylation and published our results (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 4767-4771, doi.org/10.1002/anie.201600488). In addition, we have carried out extensive efforts and collaborated with Dr. Peng Liu, a computational physical organic chemist at University of Pittsburgh, for investigating the mechanism of this stereoselective β-mannosylation. These results were just submitted (Meng, S.; † Bhetuwal, B. R.; † Nguyen, H.; † Fang, C.; Qi, X.; Saybolt, K.; Li, X.;* Liu, P.;* Zhu, J.* “β-Mannosylation via O-Alkylation of Anomeric Cesium Alkoxides: Mechanistic Studies and Synthesis of the Hexasaccharide Core of Complex Fucosylated N-Linked Glycans.” Submitted to Angew Chem., Int. Ed. († S.M., B.R.B., and H.N. contributed equally to this work)).

 

This newly developed stereoselective β-mannosylation method has been employed in the efficient synthesis/formal synthesis of several complex bioactive oligosaccahrides/glycoconjugates, including: 1) a potent calcium signal modulator acremomannolipin A (Li, X.;* Berry, N.; Saybolt, K.; Ahmed, U.; Yuan, Y. Tetrahedron Lett. 2017, 58, 2069–2072, doi.org/10.1016/j.tetlet.2017.04.049); 2) β-D-Xyl-(l→2)-β-D-Man-(1→4)-α- D-Glc-OMe, a trisaccharide oligomer of the Hyriopsis schlegelii glycosphingolipid (Bhetuwal, B. R.; Woodward, J.; Li, X.;* Zhu, J.* J. Carbohydr. Chem. 2017, 36, 162-172, doi.org/10.1080/07328303.2017.1390579); 3) a trisaccharide of Salmonella serogroup E1 capsular polysaccharides (CPS) (near completion, Hettiarachchi, I. L.; Li, X.;* Zhu, J.* Synthesis of trisaccharide oligomer of Salmonella E1 capsular polysaccharide via anomeric O–alkylation, to be submitted).   

 

Furthermore, we developed a new method for the synthesis of a variety of sugar lactols (hemiacetals) by using bromine-mediated oxidation of thioglycosides and published the work (Meng, S.; Bhetuwal, B. R.; Acharya, P. P.; Zhu, J.* J. Carbohydr. Chem. 2019, 38, 109-126, doi.org/10.1080/07328303.2019.1581889). This method will facilitate the preparation of various sugar lactols for stereoselective anomeric O-alkylation for the synthesis of complex oligosaccharides and glycoconjugates.

 

Moreover, we discovered an alkyl thiocyanate as an efficient electrophile for stereoselective sulfenylation of 2-deoxy glycosyl lithium for the synthesis of thioglycosides (S-linked glycosides) and published our findings (Acharya, P.; Baryal, K. N.; Reno, C.; Zhu, J.* Carbohydr. Res. 2017, 448, 103-109, doi.org/10.1016/j.carres.2017.06.005). Currently, we are working on extend this umpolung approach for stereoselective synthesis of α-2-deoxy-2-amino thioglycosides and will report our findings in due course.

 

Under the support of this NSF grant, the PI (Dr. Zhu) and Co-PI (Dr. Li) has given 19 invited oral presentations at fourteen different universities as well as several regional and national meetings/symposiums. The research results have also been disseminated to the community by the PI and Co-PI and their group members via a total of 36 oral and poster presentations in the regional and national meetings/symposiums. In addition, under the support of this NSF grant, five peer-reviewed articles have been published, one manuscript was just submitted, and two additional manuscripts are in preparation. Two PhD dissertations were also generated from the support of this NSF grant.

 

This research will have significant impact on medicinal chemistry and glycobiology. β-Mannosides are an important class of carbohydrates which exist in numerous biologically significant molecules including N-linked glycans, bacterial capsular polysaccharides, fungal metabolites, glycolipids, antimicrobial antibiotics and lipopolysaccharides. This mild and easily operable β-mannosylation will enable efficient stereoselective synthesis of β-mannosides for discovering useful biological probes and therapeutic agents.

 

Under the support of this NSF grant, one female and two male high school students from financially disadvantaged families and underrepresented groups (four of them were also supported by ACS Project Seed program), fourteen undergraduate students, six graduate students were offered opportunity to actively participate in this research. In addition, the co-PI of this grant, Dr. Xiaohua Li,  is also a female Professor of Chemistry. It is anticipated that those research experiences will impact their career development in the future. Most of those high school students continued their next-level education in chemistry or related programs in college. Some undergraduate students are pursuing their PharmD/PhD or MD in medical schools, while others are planning to apply for chemistry graduate program or pursue their career in industry. Two graduate students earned their PhD degrees and are working as postdoctoral researchers at various institutions. Three graduate students are currently pursuing their Ph.D. degree under the supervision of the PI.  

 

The PI participated in teaching an undergraduate course “CHEM 1910, Introduction to Research” and talked about “Chemical Synthesis of Biologically Significant Oligosaccharides” in the spring of 2015-2019 to help undergraduate student recognize the importance of chemical science. Besides, the PI pursued outreach efforts in Summer 2016-2017, such as: 1) The University of Toledo SMET EXCEL designed to prepare students who are members of groups underrepresented in higher education for success in college and increase their self-esteem, cultural awareness of diversity, and civic involvement and responsibility; 2) The University of Toledo Latino Youth Summit Overnight (LYSO) which is designed to attract Latino youth to pursue university education in the science and technology.


Last Modified: 10/15/2019
Modified by: Jianglong Zhu
